Award.AwardTitle: Gravitational Wave Transient Astrophysics with LIGO
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gravitational physics is on the edge of a discovery that will shake its foundation: the direct detection of gravitational waves, tiny oscillations of the curvature of space-time that were predicted 100 years ago by Einstein's theory of General Relativity. Gravitational waves are produced by changes in the gravitational field of accelerating masses, and their detection will reveal information from the most cataclysmic and mysterious events in the Universe: the death of a star, the collision of black holes, and the Big Bang. This new era of gravitational physics is being ushered in by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) and its sister project Virgo. This year marks the completion of hardware upgrades that form Advanced LIGO, a quantum-noise-limited laser interferometer which will probe about 1000 times more galaxies than initial LIGO. Source population studies suggest it will routinely detect gravitational waves from the collision of neutron stars and black holes. This award supports mission critical research for the detection of gravitational waves by Advanced LIGO at the Georgia Institute of Technology, for the detection, characterization and astrophysical interpretation of gravitational wave transient signals in data from the first Advanced LIGO science runs.


This project has three components: (1) participation in the LIGO-Virgo all-sky search for generic gravitational wave transients, sensitive to a wide range of compact object signatures, including core-collapse supernovae, coalescence of neutron star and/or black hole binary systems and neutron star oscillations, (2) development of innovative approaches to blending data analysis and numerical relativity, with contribution to targeted searches for binary black hole coalescences, and (3) characterization of Advanced LIGO data to enable scientific discovery, to deliver the data quality information necessary to clean the data sets and veto false positives, and to identify data quality issues early enough that they can be mitigated in the instruments, within the LIGO Detector Characterization team. The award will benefit from the long term collaboration of the PI and co-PI and a synergistic team at the GeorgiaTech Center for Relativistic Astrophysics, with experts in computational astrophysics, cosmology, particle astrophysics, astronomy, the college of computing and a strong outreach program in Atlanta, enhanced by the new ties to the LIGO Scientific Collaboration, and a firm commitment to diversity and the role of women in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The lifetime of this award witnessed breakthrough discoveries, as LIGO detected the first gravitational wave in 2015, with binary black hole (BBH) merger GW150914, and two years later LIGO and Virgo together detected the first binary neutron star (BNS) merger GW170817.  These discoveries inaugurated a new multi-messenger astrophysics, where gravitational waves together with electromagnetic radiation and neutrinos provide a multi-sensory probe of the Universe. This award supported the LIGO group at Georgia Tech, under the leadership of PIs Cadonati and Shoemaker, with four principal components.

1.  LIGO SCIENTIFIC COLLABORATION LEADERSHIP

Cadonati (PI)  led the LIGO Data Analysis Council during the first half of the award, and was later Deputy Spokesperson for the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC).  In these roles, she coordinated efforts leading to the GW150914 discovery papers and a couple dozen additional collaboration papers. In addition, Cadonati worked on the announcement of GW170817, with three collaboration papers and the ~4500 author paper with astronomers participating in the followup, as well as GW170814, the first BBH jointly discovered with Virgo.

2. PARTICIPATION IN SEARCHES FOR GRAVITATIONAL WAVE BURSTS

Our group contributed to several aspect of LIGO's searches for short-duration GW bursts, including comparisons of modeled and un-modeled waveform reconstructions and residual analyses involving searches for excess power after subtraction of best-fit templates, with the BayesWaves pipeline.

For the GW150914 burst companion paper and the burst search result in the first aLIGO science run (O1), we created multiple BBH simulations sets to estimate the sensitivity of LIGO burst searches, we conducted burst parameter estimation studies on GW150914, and contributed to various aspects of the internal LIGO review.  Our study on the systematic comparison of de-noised waveform reconstructions from LIGO's first detection with the suite of numerical relativity waveforms in the GaTech catalog corroborates and support the astrophysical interpretation of GW150914 and demonstrates how we can use the results of generic burst searches to interpret future, less well-understood signals.

We engaged in the waveform reconstruction analysis for GW170104, a BBH merger during the second science run (O2), and we had a lead role in searches for intermediate mass binary black holes (IMBH) in O1 and O2 data. We also participated to searches for Gamma Ray Burst (GRB) sources of gravitational wave transients, with particular attention to sub-threshold Fermi events, and contributed to the GRB and electromagnetic advocate program and to the GW170817 GRB-GW paper.

Our group also led the follow-up for short-duration GW emission from massive neutron star remnants following GW170817 using BayesWaves to search for dephasing in the observed signal / templates due to tidal interactions and resonances during late stages of merger.

3. DATA ANALYSIS AND NUMERICAL RELATIVITY FOR BINARY BLACK HOLE COALESCENCES:

With combined support from this award and synergistic award 1505824,  our team contributed to the creation and curation of a LIGO-Virgo catalog of Numerical Relativity (NR) waveforms. We systematically compared them to LIGO's de-noised waveform reconstructions, and used them to test how LIGO and its data analysis respond to gravitational waves of varying physical characteristics. In particular, we tested the impact of physics beyond waveform approximants used in current LIGO-Virgo searches, to address the question of whether the current models are sufficient to detect GW signals. To this end, the sensitivity of the O1 Intermediate Mass Black Hole (IMBH) search was re-estimated using NR injections that contain higher modes. We concluded that LIGO's equal-mass rate upper limits  are not affected by the omission of higher modes in the original O1 injection sets, and that those set for larger mass ratios are rather conservative. GeorgiaTech waveforms are now used directly against LIGO-Virgo data in the RapidPE analysis.

We studied the effect of incompleteness of waveform model on potential observation of false deviations from general relativity, explored systematic challenges for future gravitational wave measurements of precessing binary black holes, and contributed to LIGO-Virgo parameter estimation runs for GW170729, residuals studies and tests of general relativity.

4. ADVANCED LIGO DETECTOR CHARACTERIZATION:

During the first and second LIGO observational runs, our group participated to various efforts organized by the LSC Detector Characterization group, including data quality shifts, work on data quality detection checklists on specific event candidates, and glitch classification using GravitySpy.  Our students worked on VET, a software that evaluates the impact of data quality vetoes on the outcome of a search, liaisoned between the detector characterization group and the seismic isolation working group in LIGO, performing studies of correlations between common and differential modes and software for the identification of earthquake times using data from auxiliary channels.  With support from this award, two graduate students participated in the LSC fellows program and were in residence at the LIGO Livingston laboratory, contributing to hardware injection efforts in the months leading to the start of O2 and the characterization of the RF "Whistle" glitches in preparation for the O3 LIGO run.
